title: Rosewood and Chaparral together
content:
Hi people with more typographic tact than me (meaning basically everyone here). What do you think about Rosewood and Chaparral used in conjunction?

[http://vervesix.com/casa/bg\_myspace.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026135710/http:/vervesix.com/casa/bg_myspace.jpg "http://vervesix.com/casa/bg\_myspace.jpg")

Don’t mind the kerning.. had to do it in Photoshop. I’d like to work with the Rosewood serifs more, even make a few ligatures (e.g. the lower adjacent ligatures of the ’IS’ in DISCO). Also, do you find the leading I chose annoying at all? I feel like there are both good and bad things happening where the letters touch...

Thanks for any constructive input!  
Casey

 [‹ Most Readable Serif Font on Earth](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026135710/http:/www.typophile.com/node/35551 "Go to previous forum topic") [Lucida Grande and Optima for web ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026135710/http:/www.typophile.com/node/49924 "Go to next forum topic")

comments.content: [The reason it’s called “Rosewood Fill” is because it’s meant to be used as a fill layer to create chromatic letters](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026135710/http:/store1.adobe.com/cfusion/store/html/index.cfm?store=OLS-US&event=displayFontPackage&code=487).
James, that doesn’t prevent someone from using it in a different way does it?
